notes: Ellen: This is BBCH 10 and I am not sure if this should be {unfolding true leaf presence} or {non-senescing unfolded true leaf}. I need to discuss with Kjell. Kjell: This should be mapped as {expanding leaf presence}

field: Leaf unfolding (>=50%)
notes: Kjell: This should be mapped as {non-senescing unfolded true leaf}. There is no official BBCH code for this, but as far as I know PEP observations are always made at the whole-tree level meaning that at this stage of plant development {non-senescing unfolded true leaf} are present

field: Beginning of flowering
End of flowering
notes: Kjell: This BBCH code (69) is used to report 'end' of flowering and thus there may be NO {open flower presence}

field: First flower buds visible
notes: Ramona: I suggest that we get rid of "unopened flowers" and just keep flower buds. As I mentioned in an earlier email thread "PO:reproductive bud is very loosely defined as A bud (aka an undeveloped shoot system) that develops into a reproductive shoot system, so that in fact covers both unopened flower and inflorescence buds (as in a tree bud) and unopened flowers (as seen in herbaceous plant). Using the PO definition, I think it is sufficient for us to include only reproductive bud as a synonym of unopened flower, inflorescence bud, and flower bud.  JBD: changing this to unopened floral structure presence"

field: First individual flowers visible (still closed), G: Half of inflorescence emerged (middle of heading)
notes: Ramona: I suggest that we get rid of "unopened flowers" and just keep flower buds. As I mentioned in an earlier email thread PO:reproductive bud is very loosely defined as 'A bud (aka an undeveloped shoot system) that develops into a reproductive shoot system, so that in fact covers both unopened flower and inflorescence buds (as in a tree bud) and unopen flowers (as seen in herbaceous plant). Using the PO definition, I think it is sufficient for us to include only reproductive bud as a synonym of unopened flower, inflorescence bud, and flower bud.

field: Flower buds present, still enclosed by leaves (oilseed rape)
notes: Ramona: I suggest that we get rid of "unopened flowers" and just keep flower buds. As I mentioned in an earlier email thread "PO:reproductive bud is very loosely defined as A bud (aka an undeveloped shoot system) that develops into a reproductive shoot system, so that in fact covers both unopened flower and inflorescence buds (as in a tree bud) and unopen flowers (as seen in herbaceous plant). Using the PO definition, I think it is sufficient for us to include only reproductive bud as a synonym of unopened flower, inflorescence bud, and flower bud.

Full flowering
notes: Kjell: only used for BBCH 65, that is, 50% of flowers open

field: Inflorescence or flower buds visible, G: Beginning of heading
notes: Ramona: Beginning of heading is only for grasses, so we can't map all cases to fresh flower head presence. Actually, I don't know why we want to make this fresh flower presence, as BBCH describes it as "tip of inflorescence emerged from sheath, first spikelet just visible " which would map better to "reproductive bud presences" . We need more info from Kjell on how this one is scored.  Kjell: This must have been a mistake from me! I think ths should be mapped as {reproductive bud presence}

field: End of flowering: fruit set visible
notes: John: Need to set lower_percent = 0; Kjell: This BBCH code (69) is mainly used for flowering and thus should not be used for mapping fruiting. I would not use it for mapping presence of flowering either, since it is used to report 'end' of flowering. For a phenologist, it is useful to estimate flowering period (BBCH69-BBCH60).

field: Flowering finishing: majority of petals fallen or dry
notes: Kjell: This is a two-thing observation. Both {open flower presence} and {senescence flower presence} are correct. I would still prefer to map it as {open flower presence} as BBCH69 is more commonly used for end of flowering.

field: Beginning of leaf-fall
notes: Ramona: We think our proposal is to change this to just {abscised leaf presence} but we want to know more about how this category is determined in the field.   Our working supposition is that "Beginning of leaf fall" is when there are 0-5% of the leaves abscised, but we need more details from Kjell. In theory, 0-5% of leaves falling means there should also be 95-100% leaves on a plant, but based just on the label, we don't know what stage those leaves are in. They could be senescing, mature, or immature.KJELL: AGREE! I think it is much better to use {abscised leaf presence} only. Even if we often have to write instructions to the observers in such a way that we talk about both the leaves that are still on the tree and those that have fallen, I think it is much better if the PPO only talks about whtat we formally knows from the data. The PEP includes many different (national/regional) protocols, so if a specific protocol can be mapped to mutliple PPO classes, that is soemthing we should deal with in the phase of applying the PPO not in the phase where we are now.
